column1: The course will provide an overview on applied business research. It aims to help students to understand the process of the applied business research leading to a successful DBA thesis. The course will cover topics such as research ethics, research planning and management, research problem identification, research approach, research design, methods of data collection and data analysis. The course will also give an introduction to qualitative research methods.

By acquainting students with core quantitative methods, this course aims to help students utilize basic statistical tools and techniques appropriately for applied business research leading to a successful DBA thesis. The course will be practical rather than theoretical. Students will learn useful quantitative skills through numerous examples in business management. The main topics cover:1. Research question specification and hypothesis development suitable for doctoral level applied business research2. Data collection and organization3. Approaches to describe and summarize data statistically in terms of central tendency, dispersion, correlation, etc.4. Hypothesis testing and inferences using econometric methods including bivariate and multiple regressions5. Result interpretation and presentation using tables and figures.

This course aims at helping students to understand how to generate and test theories in applied business research using surveys and experimental methods. Students will learn skills in designing surveys and experiments, collecting and analysing behavioural data. The course will discuss how these methods advance our practical and scientific knowledge in business research suitable for a DBA thesis. The main topics cover:1. Theories about theory2. Research question specification and hypothesis development3. Different types of survey and experimental design4. Different types of behavioural data5. Hypothesis testing and statistical inferences6. Result interpretation and presentation

This course provides surveys on frontier applied business management research issues in various fields of business management. The course will cover relevant topics in selected economics and business disciplines such as Accounting, Finance and Managerial Economics.

This course provides surveys on frontier applied business management research issues in various fields of business management. The course will cover relevant topics in selected economics and business disciplines such as Management, Marketing, Operations, and Technology Innovation.

This course is designed to help students with their preparation for DBA thesis proposals. Through a research workshop-style learning process that includes presentation and interaction between participating students and teachers, students are expected to gain valuable insights and guidance that will lead to the enhanced development of their DBA thesis proposals.

This course identifies the corporate governance challenges for companies in China and East Asia, and explores various mechanisms for strengthening their governance systems. We pay particular attention to the corporate governance issues of state-owned firms and entrepreneurial / family-controlled firms, which are prevalent in China and East Asia.The course adopts a multi-disciplinary approach, using theories from economics, law, political science and sociology, to provide a theoretical framework for understanding the different ownership structures and corporate governance systems around the world. Combining theories with practical knowledge of corporate governance practice, we tackle issues such as government intervention on state and non-state firms, accounting opacity and fraud, ineffective board monitoring, expropriation of controlling owners against minority shareholders, and succession in family firms.

This course provides an introduction to FinTech such as blockchain, alternative lending, machine learning, and robo-advising. Students are expected to develop a broad understanding of the recent FinTech development and its impact in the financial industries. Students will also have hands-on and problem solving experiences that can be useful in FinTech applications and innovation. Topics may include but are not limited to: blockchain, bitcoins, smart contracts, decentralized applications, markets for smart contracts, alternative and P2P lending and crowdfunding, machine learning and its applications in FinTech such as robo-advising, AI and quantitative trading, legal issues in FinTech.

The aim of this course is to provide a solid grounding to students interested in managing various aspects of the innovation process and understanding it better from a policy perspective. The course is divided into two parts. Broadly, the first two-thirds of the course focuses more on analytic and strategic frameworks for managing innovation. This segment examines patterns of technological change and their impacts, planning for technological transitions, means for capturing economic benefits from innovation, and planning of innovation projects over time. The last third of the course examines more organizational issues involved in implementing strategies. These issues include management of teams and partnerships, learning within and across projects, the manager's role in forecasting and funding, directing and stopping innovation projects, technological entrepreneurship, and barriers to innovation. Case studies, both written and video-based, are used extensively to illustrate a range of technologies and the problems associated with developing them and bringing them to market.

This course aims to expose our students to a wide spectrum of global, regional and local business and management issues. To facilitate effective learning, specific topics will be selected for incorporating in this course: examples include trade, economics, technology, finance, market, ventures, politics, corporate governance, management practices, as well as various societal concerns. This course enables students to identify in-depth the gist behind certain selected management and business topics and to come up with insights to help corporations make better decisions in the future.

This course consists of preparatory assignments and a written study plan, followed by a five-day study week in a selected place. Students have to submit a written report and make oral presentation of their work. The goal in taking classroom sessions abroad is to expose our students to a wide spectrum of issues related to global business and management. Students will be exposed to different national environments, advantages and problems associated with various forms of international operations, and management strategies of international firms.

This course provides a systematic review of monetary policy making in major central banks (e.g., the Federal Reserve and the People's Bank of China) and the impact of policy on the global financial markets. In addition, the course offers insights on the latest development of macro financial issues in China and the interactions of these new developments within the global financial system.

This course provides an overview of the capital markets and financial institutions in the Greater China (China, Hong Kong, and Taiwan), and financing strategies for corporations in this region, specific topics include stock markets, bond markets financial intermediaries, capital raising strategies and mergers and acquisitions. Emphasis will be made on how the Greater China's different institutional factors impact the functioning of the financial markets and institutions, and in turn the financing strategies of corporations.
To explain the economic basis for financial systems and the corporate form of business organization and how they operate in various cultural and legal environments around the world.

This course critically investigates risk management functions in business; business loss exposures; tools and innovations in risk management; insurance contracts, policies and pricing; strategic operation of insurers; and government regulation/policy changes in the insurance space.

This course integrates management and investments to analyse the mergers and acquisitions (M&A) (takeover) in markets. It will include discussions of the strategic implications of M&A, its processes, sources of value, and relevant policies and regulations. Cross-border M&A will be investigated in particular and a number of cases, both successful and unsuccessful, will be dissected and best practices revealed. Post-investment management of acquisitions will be critically examined.

The objective of this course is to teach investment strategies that are based on past price history. Trading strategies such as contrarian strategy and momentum strategy are discussed extensively. The course also covers the many investor behavioral biases as well as major trading principles in technical analysis.

Independent research on an individual work basis under the general supervision of a faculty member, in any of the following areas: accounting, business economics, business law, finance, insurance, international business, management, management information systems, marketing, personnel and industrial relations, production and operations management, or real estate. Prerequisite: consent of an instructor after examination of a written research proposal outlining the research subject, objectives, and proposed methodology. The student may submit a proposal to the instructor of choice, but with the understanding that no faculty member is obliged to accept research students. The course may be taken more than once, but total units for this course may not exceed 6 units, and students cannot take 2 directed research courses in a term.

This course aims to bridge the traditional operations management theories with cutting-edge topics on how companies adjust their global operations and supply chains in the face of new challenges such as geo-political tensions, trade barriers, natural disasters and other megatrends such as global supply chain restructuring, technology decoupling, and business sustainability.

Drawing on recent theoretical development in strategy and organizational management, this course uses China as the context to study the activities, strategies, and structures of Chinese entrepreneurial firms/publicly listed companies and foreign multinational enterprises; interactions between multinational enterprises and other organizations, institutions, and markets; and the cross-border activities of firms as well as cross-country comparative studies of business practices.

This course introduces cutting-edge research topics related to managing technological innovations, such as open innovations, crowdsourcing, crowdfunding, cryptoassets, artificial intelligence (AI), and augmented reality (AR). The course will focus on the impacts of these technological innovations on firms and/or individuals and discuss the underlying theories related to these impacts.

This course introduces various methodologies for developing better marketing strategies through insightful understanding of consumers and markets. Examples include A/B testing and business experimentation, data-driven models and algorithms, lab experimentation, and applied game theory.

Effective people management and leadership are considered essential for organizational effectiveness. Organizational Behavior and leadership reside at the intersection of science, art, and craft. Drawing upon theories and hard evidence of organizational behavior and leadership science, the focus of this course is to offer state-of-the-art theories, research and practices in organizational behaviors and leadership. Sample topics include individual differences (e.g., personality traits, intelligence and genetics) and how they relate to leadership emergence and effectiveness, employee motivation, leadership development, and health and well-being.

Accounting provides the basic but fundamental information for the capital market. This course introduces the cutting-edge knowledge on how accounting interacts with the capital markets. Topics include earnings management, pricing of earnings, accounting information in quantitative investments, stock market anomalies involving accounting information, ESG reporting and investment, and the use of accounting information in contracts.

Managerial accounting permeates most essential business functions of firms. This course introduces the most up-to-date knowledge on performance measurement, incentives and compensation design, budgeting and target-setting, corporate culture, corporate governance in management, and integration of accounting and business decisions.

Students will be required to take this course every term from the time of the advancement to doctoral candidature throughout their thesis preparation. The supervisor will meet the student on a regular basis and advise the student on all matters related to thesis research. Under the supervision of the supervisor(s), students are required to employ applied research methods to conceptualize the research idea, review appropriate literature and carry out research.
